title: Dinic's algorithm
summary: Dinic's algorithm or Dinitz's algorithm is a strongly polynomial algorithm for computing the maximum flow in a flow network, conceived in 1970 by Israeli (formerly Soviet) computer scientist Yefim (Chaim) A. Dinitz.[1] The algorithm runs in O ( V 2 E ) {\displaystyle O(V^{2}E)} time and is similar to the Edmondsâ€“Karp algorithm, which runs in O ( V E 2 ) {\displaystyle O(VE^{2})} time, in that it uses shortest augmenting paths. The introduction of the concepts of the level graph and blocking flow enable Dinic's algorithm to achieve its performance.
